title: 106_s120
content: The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" is the short title of this Act. It defines the term "domestic industry" among other things. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as the producers of like or competitive articles constituting a major proportion of total domestic production in a specific geographic area of the United States. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as producers of like or competitive articles that make up a significant portion of total domestic production in a specific geographic area of the United States. The Act also allows the commission to determine the eligibility of domestic producers based on certain criteria. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as producers of like or competitive perishable agricultural products, citrus products, or potato products in a specific geographic area of the United States, whose production constitutes a significant portion of the domestic industry and primarily serves the market in that area. If there are substantial imports of a like or directly competitive product in the area, only that portion of the domestic industry is treated as such. The "Agricultural Trade Reform Act of 1999" defines "domestic industry" as producers of perishable agricultural products, citrus products, or potato products in a specific geographic area of the United States. The term "significant portion of the domestic industry in the United States" refers to an important part of the industry characterized by production in the same growing season. SEC. 3. PROVISIONAL RELIEF. Section 202(d)(1)(C) of the Trade Act of 1974 is amended to allow for provisional relief in cases where a petition alleges injury from imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products that have been monitored by the Commission for at least 90 days. This relief can be requested by the President, Trade Representative, or Committees on Ways and Means. The Committee on Ways and Means or the Committee on Finance may provide provisional relief to prevent serious injury to the domestic industry from increased imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products. The Commission must make a determination within 21 days of the request based on available information regarding the impact of these imports on the domestic industry. The Commission may waive the 90-day timeframe when considering a petition, request, or resolution related to preventing serious injury to the domestic industry from imports of perishable agricultural, citrus, or potato products. The Commission may waive the 90-day monitoring requirement if there is evidence of significant increases in production or capacity in the country of import that could cause serious injury to the domestic industry. Amendments are made to sections of the Act regarding imports of like or directly competitive products. Amendments are made to the Act regarding imports of perishable agricultural products, citrus products, and potato products. The term 'potato product' is defined as any potato product, including processed ones.
